excerpt: Spacious, indoor complex with stalls selling fresh produce, seafood & meat, plus specialty dishes.
detail_description: Omicho Market, known as the "kitchen of Kanazawa," is a bustling indoor complex with over 170 stalls offering an array of fresh produce, seafood, and meat. The market is particularly famous for its variety of fresh seafood caught in the nearby Sea of Japan, including yellowtail, shrimp available year-round, and crab starting from November. Visitors can also explore shops selling local fruits and vegetables not commonly found elsewhere.
name: Omicho Market

excerpt: Traditional neighborhood with teahouses where geisha perform, plus shops selling gold-leaf crafts.
detail_description: Higashi Chaya District, also known as The Eastern Teahouse District, is a well-preserved traditional neighborhood in Kanazawa. It features beautifully maintained teahouses and geisha houses that were once frequented by feudal lords and high-ranking officials during the Edo period. Some of these historic buildings have been transformed into restaurants and shops selling local goods, while others remain intact as teahouses for visitors to enjoy.
name: Higashi Chaya District (Eastern Teahouse District)

excerpt: Modern & large-scale displays of Japanese & international art in a circular, glass-walled building.
detail_description: The 21st Century Museum of Contemporary Art, Kanazawa is a popular art museum in Japan known for its modern and large-scale displays of Japanese and international art. The circular glass-walled building was designed without a main entrance to encourage visitors to approach from different directions, mirroring the method recommended for viewing the art inside. The museum features both traveling exhibitions and permanent installations, such as Leandro Elrich's Swimming Pool and the Colour Activity House.
name: Kanazawa 21st Century Museum of Contemporary Art

excerpt: Reconstructed 16th-century castle famous for its extensive surrounding garden, with tours.
detail_description: Kanazawa Castle Park is a reconstructed 16th-century castle that once served as the hereditary residence of the Maeda family before the 'Meiji Restoration.' The park, located in Kanazawa City, Ishikawa Prefecture, features extensive surrounding gardens and is adjacent to Kenliu Garden. Visitors can explore historical structures like Ishikawa Gate and enjoy tours of the area. The park is particularly popular during cherry blossom season when the night cherry blossoms create a stunning display.
name: Kanazawa Castle Park

excerpt: One of only 3 'perfect gardens' in Japan, this park is designed to be beautiful during every season.
detail_description: Kenroku-en is one of Japan's most celebrated landscaped gardens, known as one of the country's 'Three Famous Gardens.' The name refers to the six classical elements of an ideal garden, and it offers a seamless transition through sculpted pine trees, stone lanterns, and ponds. Originally part of a castle's grounds, this garden has developed over several hundred years and is designed to be beautiful in every season.
name: Kenroku-en

excerpt: Village featuring cobblestone streets & former samurai homes, plus shops & restaurants.
detail_description: Naga-machi District, located on the west side of the city and near Korinbo District, is a charming village known for its cobblestone streets and well-preserved samurai homes. Visitors can explore a collection of restored samurai houses along two picturesque canals, with the option to enter and look around. Walking north along the canal behind Kohrinbo 109 Building and then south along the next canal leads to various restaurants and cafes.
name: Nagamachi Buke Yashiki District

detail_description: Kanazawa Station is a popular landmark known for its striking architecture and convenient layout. The station features the impressive Tsuzumi-mon Gate, inspired by the traditional Noh drum, which welcomes travelers with its remarkable design. Additionally, the huge glass Motenashi Dome provides shelter from the elements and adds to the station's allure. Surrounding the station are numerous shopping and dining options, including Kanazawa Forus with seven floors of shops and restaurants.
name: Kanazawa Station

excerpt: Museum dedicated to D.T. Suzuki with educational programs, a contemplation space & tranquil gardens.
detail_description: The D.T. Suzuki Museum, located in a quiet alley, is a tribute to the renowned Japanese Buddhist philosopher D.T. Suzuki. The museum offers educational programs and features a contemplation space and serene gardens for visitors to enjoy. It provides an immersive experience into Suzuki's life and his Zen-like philosophy. The museum consists of the Entrance Building, Exhibition Building, and Thinking Building connected by a corridor leading to the Suzuki Dazhuo Pavilion near his birthplace.
name: D.T. Suzuki Museum

excerpt: Historic Shinto shrine with a grand entry gate featuring stained glass, a large garden & a pond.
detail_description: Oyama Shrine is a historic Shinto shrine in Kanazawa, Japan. It is dedicated to Maeda Toshiie, the first lord of the local Maeda clan. The shrine features a grand entry gate with stained glass and a large garden with a pond. One of its most distinctive features is the unusual gate, which has Chinese-influenced detailing at the base and a narrow, Dutch-influenced second story that was believed to have once been a lighthouse.
name: Oyama Shrine

detail_description: Nestled near the picturesque Kenrokuen Garden, Kanazawa Castle is a captivating historical site that dates back to the 1580s. Although it lacks a castle tower, visitors can explore its well-preserved walls and gates, offering a glimpse into Japan's rich heritage. The surrounding park provides an immersive experience of ancient life. Restoration work on Ninomaru Palace is underway, promising an enhanced visit in the future.
name: Kanazawa Castle

excerpt: Kanazawa is the capital of Ishikawa Prefecture, on Japan’s central Honshu Island. It's known for well-preserved Edo-era districts, art museums and regional handicrafts. Kenrokuen Garden, begun in the 17th century, is celebrated for its classic landscape designs incorporating ponds and streams. Adjacent Kanazawa Castle was built in the 1580s, after the defeat of the Peasant’s Kingdom, Japan's only Buddhist fiefdom.
detail_description: Kanazawa, the capital of Ishikawa Prefecture in Japan, is a city steeped in history and tradition. It boasts well-preserved Edo-era districts, art museums, and regional handicrafts. The famous Kenrokuen Garden, with its classic landscape designs featuring ponds and streams, is a must-see attraction. Kanazawa Castle, built in the 1580s after the defeat of Japan's only Buddhist fiefdom, is also nearby.
name: Kanazawa

excerpt: Showcase of 500-plus phonographs & over 20,000 records, with regular sound demos & a vinyl library.
detail_description: The Kanazawa Phonograph Museum is a delightful and unique attraction that showcases an extensive collection of over 500 phonographs and more than 20,000 records. Visitors can enjoy regular sound demonstrations and explore a vinyl library at this charming institution. The museum spans three floors, offering a comprehensive journey through the history of phonographs from Thomas Edison's early experiments to modern times. It also features antique radio consoles and a fascinating collection of old photographs.
name: Kanazawa Phonograph Museum

detail_description: Kanazawa Castle Ruins is a historic site located in the Ishikawa Prefecture on the Japanese West coast. The city is known for its well-preserved Edo period architecture and offers a number of peaceful attractions for visitors. Some of the must-visit places include Kenrokuen, one of Japan's most beautiful gardens, Nagamachi Samurai District, Kanazawa Shinise Memorial Hall, and various temples and shrines such as Teramachi and Oyama Shrine.
name: Kanazawa Castle Ruins

excerpt: Elegant museum showcasing collections of regional Japanese artwork & artifacts in a modern facility.
detail_description: The Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Art is an elegant and modern facility showcasing a collection of regional Japanese artwork and artifacts. The museum features a traditional collection, displaying ancient Japanese paintings, evocative sculptures, local folk crafts, and treasures of the Maeda family. It also hosts traveling exhibits and contains masterpieces of Kutani and other Kaga arts. The building itself is quite elegant with tall structures and marble decorations.
name: Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Art

excerpt: Kanazawa's largest chaya district, with restored 1800s wooden teahouses, shops & restaurants.
detail_description: Kazuemachi Chaya District is one of the three well-preserved traditional entertainment districts in Kanazawa, Japan. It features restored 1800s wooden teahouses, shops, and restaurants along the Asano River. The picturesque landscape with tightly packed buildings and illuminated lanterns creates a serene ambiance for a leisurely stroll.
name: Kazuemachi Chaya District

excerpt: Historic district featuring craft shops, Edo-period teahouses & a museum with tours of the area.
detail_description: Nishi Chaya District is a historic area in Kanazawa, featuring craft shops, Edo-period teahouses, and a museum offering tours of the district. While smaller and less crowded than its eastern counterpart, it still offers a glimpse into the city's affluent past. The district is home to venerated businesses serving the city's elite today, with cozy restaurants and bars waiting to be discovered.
name: Nishi Chaya District

excerpt: Displays of elaborate masks & kimonos used in Noh theater, a tradition dating to the 14th century.
detail_description: The Kanazawa Noh Museum is a modern exhibition hall showcasing the elaborate masks and kimonos used in Noh theater, a traditional Japanese art form dating back to the 14th century. The museum offers avant-garde architecture, wide outdoor spaces, and interactive exhibits suitable for both adults and children. Visitors can immerse themselves in the world of Noh through reproductions of Noh stages, displays of precious Noh costumes, and the opportunity to try on traditional Noh attire.
name: Kanazawa Noh Museum

excerpt: Kanazawa district known for its feudal-era homes & gardens, as well as the Shinise Kinenkan Museum.
detail_description: Nagamachi is a well-preserved neighborhood in Kanazawa, located southeast of Kanazawa Castle. It was once the home of high to mid-ranking samurai soldiers during the Edo period. The area features traditional residences carefully preserved to represent samurai life from that era. Visitors can explore picturesque narrow lanes and visit the Nomura House, a beautifully preserved Edo-period mansion with a stunning garden.
name: Nagamachi

excerpt: The Nomura family's restored Edo-era home features samurai artifacts, a garden & a tea room.
detail_description: Nomura-ke Samurai Residence is a meticulously restored Edo-era home that once belonged to the Nomura family, a wealthy samurai clan. The house features interconnecting tatami rooms that open onto a serene inner garden with a meandering stream, trees, rocks, and stone lanterns. Additionally, there is an elegant upstairs tearoom and a gallery displaying samurai weapons and heirlooms.
name: Nomura-ke Samurai Heritage Residence

excerpt: Strikingly designed & colored gate with twisting supporting pillars, modelled on a traditional drum.
detail_description: The Tsuzumi-mon Gate at Kanazawa Station is a strikingly designed and colored gate with twisting supporting pillars, resembling a traditional drum. The large red structure greets visitors as they exit the west side of the station. Unlike a regular torii gate, the pillars of this gate are modeled after tsuzumi drums used in traditional Japanese Noh theater, giving them their unique shape and name.
name: Tsuzumi-mon Gate

excerpt: Contemporary displays on the production of gold leaf, plus porcelain & lacquerware covered in gold.
detail_description: The Kanazawa Yasue Gold Leaf Museum offers contemporary exhibits showcasing the production of gold leaf, as well as porcelain and lacquerware adorned with gold. The museum is a tribute to the city's rich heritage in traditional crafts like Kaga yuzen dyeing, Kanazawa gold leaf, and Kutani-ware. Recognized by UNESCO as a Creative City for Crafts and Folk Arts, Kanazawa aims to preserve its cultural legacy while attracting visitors from around the world.
name: Kanazawa Yasue Gold Leaf Museum

detail_description: "The Old Site of Mr. Kurando Terashima's House" is a historic site in Kanazawa Yuwaku, featuring ten well-preserved buildings including samurai residences, farm houses, and an inn from the Edo period. The former residence of Kurando Terashima, a middle-class samurai, offers insight into the lifestyle of that era. The house retains its original garden with over 300-year-old azaleas that bloom in spring and colorful foliage in autumn.
name: The Old Site of Mr. Kurando Terashima's House
address: 史跡寺島蔵人邸, 10-3 Otemachi, Kanazawa, Ishikawa 920-0912, Japan

excerpt: Historic Japanese garden next to Kanazawa Castle with walking paths, a pond & night lighting.
detail_description: Gyokuseninmaru Park is a charming Japanese garden situated adjacent to Kanazawa Castle. The park features a serene pond with three islands, a picturesque waterfall, and a circular walking path adorned with small bridges. Visitors can also enjoy matcha green tea and wagashi sweets at the small tea house within the garden. Despite its proximity to the castle, the park maintains a tranquil atmosphere with limited tourist traffic, making it an ideal spot for relaxation and scenic appreciation.
name: Gyokusenin Maru Garden

excerpt: Lessons on the art of dyeing fabric with designs from nature, plus kimono rentals & a museum.
detail_description: The Kaga-Yuzen Kimono Center in Kanazawa offers a unique experience for visitors interested in traditional Japanese crafts and fashion. The center provides lessons on the art of dyeing fabric with designs inspired by nature, as well as kimono rentals and a museum showcasing the rich heritage of Kanazawa. UNESCO recognized Kanazawa as its first Creative City for Crafts and Folk Arts, highlighting the city's commitment to preserving its cultural legacy.
name: Kaga-Yuzen Kimono Center

excerpt: Built in 1863 for a feudal lord's mother, this villa features period art & artifacts, plus a garden.
detail_description: Seison-kaku is a villa located within Kenroku-en Garden, built in 1863 by Nariyasu Maeda for his mother. The villa features period art and artifacts, with a design that integrates Western materials. The Ekken-no-Ma (Audience Room) showcases custom-made carpets and cypress openwork screens adorned with splendid natural pigments. Despite its unassuming exterior, the villa's vibrant colors and attention to detail make it a breathtaking sight.
name: Seison-kaku

excerpt: Tours are offered of this unique Buddhist temple with hidden rooms, secret passageways & traps.
detail_description: Myouryuji, also known as the Ninja Temple, is a fascinating Buddhist temple located in the Teramachi district. Built by the Maeda clan, it served as a secret armed outpost to protect Kanazawa Castle. The temple features hidden rooms, secret passageways, maze-like stairwells, and trap doors designed for stealth and deception. Although it doesn't actually house ninjas, it was once used to conceal a secret army of samurai.
name: Myouryuji (Ninja Temple)

detail_description: When visiting Kanazawa, don't miss the Kanazawa Shinise Memorial Hall, located in the Nagamachi Samurai District. This museum offers a glimpse into traditional Chinese pharmacy practices from the Edo-era and showcases a diverse collection of local crafts, including intricately handcrafted temari woven balls. The museum also features rotating exhibitions on local history and crafts. What sets this museum apart is its bilingual signage in Japanese and English, making it accessible to international visitors.
name: Kanazawa Shinise Memorial Hall

excerpt: Small museum featuring 2 Edo period homes & a garden that portray the life of samurai foot soldiers.
detail_description: The Kanazawa City Ashigaru Museum, located in Nagamachi, offers a fascinating glimpse into the lives of lower-caste samurai foot soldiers during the Edo period. The museum features two reconstructed homes and a garden that showcase the relatively austere lifestyle of the ashigaru. Visitors can explore these well-preserved houses to gain insight into how these lower-ranked samurai lived in the past.
name: Kanazawa City Ashigaru Museum

excerpt: Museum with historical displays & an interactive exhibit allowing visitors to wear ancient costumes.
detail_description: The Ishikawa Prefectural History Museum is located next to the National Crafts Museum in a serene green area. The museum offers historical displays and an interactive exhibit where visitors can try on ancient costumes. It features easy-to-understand exhibitions with numerous models and reproductions, providing insights into the history of Ishikawa prefecture.
name: Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of History

excerpt: Displays of red & gold lacquerware, colorful hand-painted porcelain & local embroidery.
detail_description: The Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Traditional Arts and Crafts in Kanazawa City offers a comprehensive overview of folk crafts in the region. The museum showcases 36 designated traditional crafts, including red & gold lacquerware, hand-painted porcelain, local embroidery, Kutani porcelain, Kaga Yuzen silk, and more. Visitors can explore exhibits related to various speciality crafts in the sleek and well-designed museum located beside Kenrokuen Garden.
name: Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Traditional Arts and Crafts

excerpt: Low mountain & scenic hiking area with a shrine & panoramic views of Kanazawa.
detail_description: Mount Utatsu, also known as Utatsuyama, is a picturesque hiking area located east of Kanazawa. The mountain offers scenic views of the city and is relatively easy to access, with just one bus service taking visitors there in less than 30 minutes. Along the way up from Higashi Cha-ya, hikers can explore small shrines scattered throughout the path. From the mountaintop, one can enjoy panoramic vistas of Kanazawa on clear days.
name: Mount Utatsu

excerpt: Shinto shrine originally built in the 700s & relocated to this spot in 1880, with festivals.
detail_description: Ishiura Shrine is a historic Shinto shrine in Kanazawa, originally built in the 700s and relocated to its current location in 1880. The shrine is known for its festivals and cute mascots, particularly a little white dog that has become its symbol. Visitors can also obtain goshuin stamps inside the office/shop area as a memento of their visit.
name: Ishiura Shrine

detail_description: Yanagi Sori Design Memorial is a small museum associated with Kanazawa College of Art, showcasing an intriguing collection of the renowned designer's works and design materials. The museum offers a glimpse into the thoughtful artistry behind everyday household products. Visitors can explore the excellent designs of Sori Yanagi, known for practical, clean, and beautiful designs that enhance modern lives. Notable exhibits include the iconic butterfly stool at the entrance.
name: Yanagi Sori Design Memorial

excerpt: Downtown shopping area with department stores, boutiques, global brands & underground parking.
detail_description: Korinbo is the bustling heart of Kanazawa's central commercial and business district, offering a diverse shopping experience. This downtown area features major department stores like Daiwa and shopping complexes such as Korinbo Atrio and Tokyu Square Korinbo. Visitors can explore an array of boutiques, global brands, and fashion outlets at these locations. Additionally, the underground parking facilities make it convenient for shoppers to access the area.
name: Korinbo

excerpt: Wooded park with a viewpoint overlooking the city & Sea of Japan, plus summer irises & hydrangeas.
detail_description: Utatsuyama Park in Kanazawa offers a variety of experiences for visitors. It features hiking trails and a viewpoint that provides stunning vistas of Kanazawa and the Sea of Japan. The park is known for its serene atmosphere, with wooded areas, walking paths, and historical monuments to explore. Despite its popularity, the park remains relatively uncrowded compared to the city center. Accessible by bus or car, it also offers panoramic views of Kanazawa city and ample parking space.
name: Utatsuyama Park

excerpt: Buzzing Katamachi centers on a neon-lit intersection known as the Scramble, where pubs, clubs, karaoke bars, and live rock venues are packed into high-rise buildings and along narrow lanes. Riverside gourmet restaurants serve oysters and prime cuts of local Noto-gyu beef, while casual eateries specialize in Kanazawa-style katsu curry and rice. Upscale department stores and hip indie boutiques draw daytime crowds.
detail_description: Katamachi, a vibrant district in Kanazawa, is known for its bustling nightlife and diverse dining scene. The area features the famous Scramble intersection, surrounded by high-rise buildings housing pubs, clubs, karaoke bars, and live rock venues. Visitors can indulge in gourmet restaurants serving local delicacies like oysters and Noto-gyu beef or savor casual eateries offering Kanazawa-style katsu curry.
name: Katamachi

detail_description: Kanazawa Tours offers a variety of experiences, including a visit to Kouji Park in Ono-machi to explore the Yamato Soy Sauce Brewery. The free tour provides insight into the production of soy sauce, featuring demonstrations and samples. Additionally, travelers can enjoy private tours led by knowledgeable guides such as Nozomi and Yuka, who offer valuable information and recommendations for local restaurants. With their expertise, visitors can uncover hidden gems and enhance their overall travel experience in Kanazawa.
name: Kanazawa Tours

detail_description: The Kanazawa Central Tourist Information Center is conveniently located near the Higashi Chaya and Kazue Machi districts, accessible by taking the Right Loop of the Kanazawa Loop Bus and getting off at the Hashibacho stop. Visitors have praised the center for its kind and courteous service, providing helpful directions to nearby tourist spots. Additionally, tourists have enjoyed Japanese cultural experiences recommended by the staff, such as traditional shows featuring music, dance, drums, and folk songs.
name: Kanazawa Central Tourist Information Center
address: 金沢ニューグランドビル 1階, 4-1 Minamicho, Kanazawa, Ishikawa 920-0919, Japan

excerpt: 17th-century green space with lush foliage & stone lanterns, plus traditional tea ceremonies.
detail_description: Gyokusen-en Nishida Family Garden is a 17th-century green space located next to Kanazawa Castle Park. It was reconstructed in 2015 and features lush foliage, stone lanterns, a small waterfall, bridges, and traditional elements. The garden's focal point is the Gyokusen-an Rest House. It offers traditional tea ceremonies and is illuminated on Friday and Saturday evenings. The water flowing in its ponds comes from Kenrokuen Garden's Kasumiga Pond.
name: Gyokusen-en Nishida Family Garden

excerpt: Restored gate standing east of the of Kanazawa Castle & facing Kenrokuen Garden.
detail_description: Ishikawa-mon Gate is a restored gate located east of Kanazawa Castle, facing Kenrokuen Garden. It has historical significance as the residential castle of the Maeda family since 1583. The gate survived a fire in 1881 that destroyed other castle walls and was part of a restoration project from 1998 to rebuild wooden structures on a large scale.
name: Ishikawa-mon Gate

excerpt: Quiet Teramachi is a hub of feudal-era Buddhist temples, including Shogetsu-ji, with its centuries-old cherry tree, and Daien-ji with its guardian statue made from human bones. Some resident Zen monks host meditation sessions and serve tofu-based shojin-ryori meals to visitors. Formal kaiseki restaurants and hip European-style bakeries dot narrow backstreets, while peaceful greenway paths line the Sai River.
detail_description: Teramachi is a serene neighborhood filled with ancient Buddhist temples, such as Shogetsu-ji and Daien-ji, where Zen monks offer meditation sessions and traditional tofu-based meals. The area also boasts formal kaiseki restaurants, European-style bakeries, and peaceful greenway paths along the Sai River. On the other side of the river lies a cluster of small Buddhist temples, including the famous Myoryu-ji Temple known as the 'Ninja Temple.'
name: Teramachi

detail_description: Kanazawa Umimirai Library, also known as the "cake box," is a contemporary architectural marvel in Kanazawa's western district. Designed by Kazumi Kudo and Hiroshi Horiba, this library stands out with its unique integration of interior and exterior spaces. Completed in 2011, it resembles a forest with soft light and an open ambiance. The building features minimal columns, high ceilings, and natural light streaming through dot windows.
name: Kanazawa Umimirai Library

detail_description: Tentokuin is a remarkable Soto Zen temple in Kanazawa, established as the family temple of Tamahime in the early 17th century. The grand and solemn gate welcomes visitors to explore its beautiful interiors and discover its romantic history. One of its unique features is the karakuri puppet show titled 'Tamahime and Tentokuin Monogatari,' which offers performances at specific times during the day.
name: Tentokuin

detail_description: Shofukaku garden is located next to the Ishikawa Prefectural Museum of Art's Hirosaka Annex in the Honda Forest. The garden was originally the residence of Mr. Honda, the chief retainer of the Kaga clan, and has a rich history dating back to 1922. Visitors can enter from a walking path and explore for free.
name: Shofukaku Garden

detail_description: Located on the grounds of Kanazawa Castle, Ozaki Shrine is a small yet culturally significant structure dedicated to Tokugawa Ieyasu, the founder of the Tokugawa shogunate. Despite its size, this charming shrine stands out with its intricate details and intimate setting. The bright red vermilion gate and buildings create a striking contrast against the lush greenery surrounding it. It's a lovely spot for both prayer and sightseeing.
name: Ozaki Shrine

excerpt: Ishikawa is a prefecture on the Japanese island of Honshu. Sitting on the seacoast, the capital city of Kanazawa is home to the “perfect garden” of Kenroku-en, designed to be beautiful during every season. The adjacent Kanazawa Castle, once home to feudal lords, has been partly reconstructed. Across the Asano River, teahouses from the Edo period have been preserved in the Higashi Chaya District.
detail_description: Ishikawa, a prefecture located on the Japanese island of Honshu, is home to the captivating city of Kanazawa. This coastal city boasts the renowned Kenroku-en garden, designed to showcase beauty in every season, and the partially reconstructed Kanazawa Castle from the feudal era. The Higashi Chaya District preserves teahouses from the Edo period across the Asano River.
name: Ishikawa

excerpt: Funky exhibition space festooned with surreal works of art made from dried flowers & citrus peels.
detail_description: HIMITO is a one-of-a-kind exhibition space in Kanazawa, featuring an array of surreal artworks crafted from dried flowers and citrus peels. The artist behind this unique approach to art is Shunkou-san, who not only creates these captivating pieces but also owns a cafe along the Saikawa River.
name: HIMITO

detail_description: Go Go Curry is a well-known curry chain with locations all over Japan, and the original store can be found in Kanazawa. The distinctive black, thick roux used in their Kanazawa Curry gives it a unique flavor and serves as the base for their original curry. The main store is conveniently located within Kanazawa station itself. The design and atmosphere of the restaurant are quite standard for a curry house, but the menu is easy to navigate.
name: Go Go Curry Kanazawa Station Main Shop
address: Japan, 〒920-0858 Ishikawa, Kanazawa, Kinoshinbomachi, 1−1 金沢百番街 Anto, 内
